Authors:
Angelica Marsberg, Martin Kemler, Fahimeh Jami, Jan Hendrik
Nagel, Alisa Postma-Smidt, Sanushka Naidoo, Michael J. Wingfield, Joseph
W Spatafora, Bernard Slippers, Pedro W. Crous
Title:
Botryosphaeria dothidea: A latent pathogen of global
importance to woody plant health
Keywords:
Botryosphaeria dothidea; Endophyte; Latent pathogen;
Quarantine; Climate change; Global pathogen
Abstract:
The genus Botryosphaeria is typified by B. dothidea
(Botryosphaeriaceae, Botryosphaeriales). Botryosphaeria dothidea is one
of the most important and widespread canker and dieback pathogens of
trees worldwide. The latent infection phase is of particular importance
as the fungus survives as an endophyte for prolonged periods and then
causes disease when the host is stressed. This implies that the fungus
can easily go undetected by quarantine systems in traded live plants,
fruits and other plant parts. This pathogen profile synthesises the
current understanding of this fungus pertaining to its current
distribution, confirmed host associations and the impact that climate
change may have. The genome has also revealed important aspects of its
diversity, mating and potential host interactions. Taxonomy:
Botryosphaeria dothidea (Moug. ex Fr) Ces. & De Not, 1863. Kingdom
Fungi, Phylum Ascomycota, Class Dothideomycetes, Order
Botryosphaeriales, Family Botryosphaeriaceae, Genus Botryosphaeria,
Species dothidea Host range: Confirmed on more than 24 host genera,
including woody plant families such as Vachellia (previously Acacia),
Eucalyptus, Vitis and Pistachio. Disease symptoms: Associated with twig,
branch and stem cankers, tip and branch dieback, fruit rot, blue stain
and plant death Useful websites:  The Botryosphaeria Site for detailed
morphological descriptions (http://www.crem.fct.unl.pt/botryosphaeria_site/); 
